facts.fact: The 'Cheers' bar (Bull & Finch) has NEVER looked like the TV show inside. The actual set was in Hollywood!
Boston's Tremont Street subway (opened 1897) was the first subway in North America.
The Boston Molasses Disaster of 1919 killed 21 people when a tank holding 2.3 million gallons exploded. You can supposedly still smell molasses on hot days.
Fenway Park's Green Monster is exactly 37 feet tall. It was built that way to prevent people from watching games for free from outside.
Boston Common (1634) is the oldest public park in the United States. It was originally used as a cow pasture.
The Fig Newton cookie was named after Newton, Massachusetts.
Samuel Adams (the beer) is named after a Revolutionary War patriot who was actually a brewer!
Boston has more Irish pubs per capita than Dublin, Ireland.
The first Dunkin' Donuts opened in Quincy, MA in 1950. America runs on Dunkin' because of Massachusetts!
The Boston Marathon is the world's oldest annual marathon (since 1897) and one of the most prestigious.
MIT students once hacked the Harvard-Yale football game scoreboard to show MIT winning.
Boston's streets are so confusing because they were originally cow paths that got paved over.
The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum heist in 1990 remains the largest unsolved art theft. $500 million in art is still missing!
Boston was the first city in America to have a public library (1653) and the first to have a subway (1897).
The Boston accent ('pahk the cah') comes from early English settlers who dropped their 'R's. Similar to British English!
